text: Bottle from Yamaya. Getting close to its drink by, so I dont expect the best. English nose, herbal hops, citrus, spice, tobacco, light caramel malts. Medium amber-orange, cleear, with a low head. Very hopyp flavor, quite bitter, spicy, nice Enlgish hops, some toffee and biscuits. Pretty solid stuff all around and would like to try it absolutely fresh.

Pours a dark, hazy golden with a full, foamy white head. The aroma is a little sweet. It has toffee, toasted malts, apple, nuts, minor bread, and minor floral hops. The taste takes a step back. There is a powerful bitterness to this one, and has toffee, nuts, and floral hops. Long. bitter floral aftertaste. This is light in body, with a thinner texture, and has average carbonation. Not bad.
Hazy orange colour. Aroma and flavour have bready notes and light fruity hops. Lasting bitter finish.

BOTTLE. (Drunk Sep23-16 BBNov13). Murky gold pour with minimal white head.. Sweet toffee apple nose.. Thin malty base, some sweet biscuit in middle, fades quickly.. Age hasnt helped, yet wasnt that high on it fresh.. Sourced cellarbrations @ Capel

Glass on tap@ Dodson St beer garden. Sweet malt nose. Golden amber beer with solid white head. Fine carbonation. Light body, zingy hoppy taste. Sharply bitter finish. Some dark fruit apparent, gets better as it warms, served too cold.

Bottle 500ml. [Big gusher. Bottle was kind of warm and misshanded, but still this felt like overreacting].
Pours golden with gushing off-white bubly head. Some soapy lacing. Aroma is of malt, nuts, bread, citrus. Taste is of malt, bread, some caramel, citrus, bitterness. Palate: Medium body, weird medium-high carbonation (gushing). Overall: Good, and not too earthy as EPAs can sometime be. Carbonation seems problematic.
500 ml bottle. Pours a light clear amber with moderate head. Aromas of toasted malts and light fruit. Flavors of same with a bit of biscuits and a grassy finish.

Pours an almost clear golden/amber with a decent size off-white head. An appetizing aroma of bright citrus, grassy hop and sweetened malt. Taste is similar, a good malt and citrus balance. Good medium-light feel with quite a clean finish, not cloying.

Bottle (500 ml) at home. BB Feb 2016 so definitely a few months old. Slow gusher. Hazy orangey-golden with a medium spotty off-white head, moderate retention, leaving little to no lacing. Aroma is of biscuity malts along caramel, herbal notes and mineral notes. Taste is biscuity with herbal and earthy notes as well as caramel and mild spiciness. Medium body. Moderate to medium carbonation. Herbal finish. Moderately dry. The front label say its "creamy and tart" which isnt the case at all. Still, its not bad at all and its rather easy drinking.

Bottle share at the Ale House, Chelmsford. Pours a slightly hazy light golden colour with a good sized white head. Light hoppy/floral aroma with citrus and biscuit notes. Medium sweetness with growing bitterness level. Medium/light body, texture quite creamy. A very drinkable pale ale.

Bottle, Ale House. 

Nice musty aroma and perfume. Bubblegum and clove. Biscuit malt notes. Some sharp toffee notes. Interesting. Good Pale Ale. Well-made.

Draft at Taps Beer Bar, Mont Kiara. Poured a clear medium amber with a frothy white head. The aroma is light resin hop, biscuit malt, toffee caramel. The flavour is moderate bitter with a nice crisp citrus hop palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation. A fresh, easy drinking pale ale.
Bottle. Bronze with a small head. Gentle bitterness that gradually dominates.Medium body. Claims to be an English Pale Ale but I thought it was more like a classy bitter.

Bottle from local Yamaya. Light caramel nose, some citrus, other mild fruit, light grass, and piney hops. Hazy orange/amber color, thick beige head, sticky slow-drooping lace. Thin maltiness in initial, some decent bittering, grass, and a somewhat dry finish. Medium body. "Perfection" .... well, thats a stretch, but it is a pretty solid pale ale. Smooth and mellow.

500ml bottle from Beerhive. Pours clear golden amber, thin white head nice lacing. Aromas are creamy, biscuit, light saline note, citrus. Taste is more cream and biscuits, rich tea maybe. Redcurrant fruitiness develops. Nice crisp finish. Solid.
Keg at Spitfire. Pours clear amber, nose is toffee, fruity, taste is dry, light fruit.

500ml Bottle from Costco courtesy of Ray. Renaissance Perfection English Pale Ale 5%. Served in a pint glass. It pours an exceedingly clear copper gold with a thin head of off-white foam. It has a really nice lemony sweet malt aroma, very appetizing. Medium to light bodied with a scratchy carbonation. The taste is not bad, earthy, sweet, lemony hops and fairly balanced. Nowhere near as cloyingly sweet as I usually get from an English IPA - pretty good. One of Renaissances better beers.
[5921-20131012] 500mL bottle. Bready grains aroma. Hazy, amber orange body with a quick foamy white head. Bitter grainy flavour has a toasted note. Medium body. Average. (7/3/7/3/13) 3.3

Aroma: fruity, floral hops. Appearance: clear gold, small, creamy, white head. Taste: light bitter. Palate: bitters continue, flowers, getting quite dry in the finish. Overall: nice APA, yet struggles to stand out. Pint at The Globe, Hong Kong.
(bottle) clear amber colour with a small brown head; aromas of fruit, soda pop; balanced flavour with a long light bitter finish

500ml bottle from the LCBO. Pours hazy orange amber with tiny white head that quickly disappears. Nose is toffee and biscuit with faint citrus. taste starts with sweet malts with a decent level of bitterness at the back end. Grapefruit and grass are evident. Medium slick mouth with slightly soft carbonation. Decent bu nothing outstanding.

pours hazy bright golden orange with a small but persistent off-white head, some lacing patterns. toasted grainy malts - toasted bread, crust, soft caramel and nuts, fruitiness - oranges and apricots, lightly piney and earthy - well dosed, fresh cut grass, chalk, pepper. low carbonation - slightly lacking, light body - oily, dry herbal-grassy-earthy-spicy finish. enjoyed!
UPDATED: OCT 26, 2014 An enjoyable brew with no features (or faults) to stand out from the crowded field of antipodean IPAs.

500 mL bottle from the LCBO, served in a pint glass. Pours clear amber with a small off-white head that fades slowly to a thin cover and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has notes of pine, caramel, biscuit malts and flowers. The flavour is balanced between mild piney bitterness and mild toasted malty sweetness. There are delicate grassy hops and biscuity malts as well. The finish is medium in length and moderately bitter. On the palate it is light-medium in body with a dryish texture and soft carbonation. Overall this is a nice English style pale ale. It is more subtle and balanced than the Discovery American style variant. A nice session ale, very well done. 2013-06-06

2013-10-14. Hazy bright orange amber small frothy off white head. 3+ mild aroma of muted green hops. Flavour is mildly bitter throughout, light caramel touches, light green hops and muted citrus. 7+ Smooth average plus palate. Okay. Bottle from the LCBO, Toronto
Bottle. Pours a dark orange colour, aroma is malty and fruity, taste lightly bitter, with a dry bitter finish.
The head is nice, the body golden. It smells hoppy, intensive, aromatic. The taste is hoparomatic, flowery, bit bitter, more aromatic, balanced and nice!

bottle. Cloudy orange colour, massive head. Citrus and berries, long bitter finish, Some yeast flavours as well. Very interesting, well balanced. Way too much carbonation. This one improved significantly by sitting in the glass for 30 minutes.

Great earthy, fruity and spicy aromas and flavours. Good amount of bitterness but let down by being way over-carbonated. Less carbonation would improve palate and appearance and probably taste and my score would probably be closer to 4/5.
500 ml bottle from LCBO. Pale amber colour with thin white head. Aromas is light toffee, biscuit. Taste is floral and somewhat fruity. Good quality beer.

Bottle: Poured a hazy amber color ale with a relatively large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of light dry hoppy notes with dry caramel malt notes that are also noticeable. Taste is a nice enough mix between dry caramel malt notes with some dry hoppy notes with light floral undertones. Body is quite full for style with good carbonation. Ok, but in the end this is not a style that I really dig.

Bottle from LCBO. Pours clear amber with a foamy beige head. Fruity aroma with caramel and pepper. Rich taste of bready malts, toasted grains, toffee, and English hops; great! Creamy and full body, feels like a cask ale. Love it; one of the best English Pale Ales Ive had.

500 ml bottle. Pale golden-amber pour with a thin white head. The aroma is softly malty with a light toffee and sweet toasted biscuit character. There is a softly floral/fruity hop aroma and a nice moderate bitterness. Nicely balanced without any of the oxidation problems Id seen in many of the other products that have come in. Lovely, quaffable ale.
Pours a murky brown with a small white wispy top. Aroma is toffee and bready grains. Taste is deep toffee and caramel grains. Rich nails the English style to a tee.

Pours a manuka honey gold, with a ridiculously foamy head. The aroma is dry, medical, hoppy, floral, spice, grass, with a bit of biscuit malty notes and toffee. The flavour starts with a dry medical note, a herbal bitterness throughout, with bits of biscuit malt notes to help balance things out. Its interesting, but I dont think Id buy it again.

unlike their other pale ales, they nailed this british style ale. Gorgeous, pungent nose of juicy UK hops. big notes of fresh grass, and biscuity malts. medium to high bitter finish, with a great hops.

When I popped the cap off the bottle, foam exploded from the bottle and overflowed! I let the bottle settle for a bit, when i poured it there was an enormous amount of head in glass!
Besides this, the aroma was quite pleasant with notes of grass, floral, spices, crackers, and toffee. The taste notes included tart, toffee, slight bitterness, caramel, and a carbonation bight to finish..
Not a bad beer at all, the carbonation issues set aside that is

Tap at mane liquor. Nice golden yellow pour with a creamy white head. Nose is quite malt driven, bready/caramel malts with floral grassy hops. Taste is much the same quite bready with earthy hops/spices. Nice floral bitterness. Something different more of an English style pale ale. Not bad!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Slowbeer. Brownish-amber, reasonable lasting head, strong toffee and dried flower aromas. Definitely very British and better than many from Britain. Loved it.

Just finished their American Pale Ale and did not like it, so lets hope this one is much better (as I do like all of their other brews). This English Pale Ale has a huge bubbly head that lasts longer and delivers some light patchy lace. Slightly hazy and golden-amber, but more on the amber side for this one. Hoppy nose at first, but after breathing, fruit malt come out to balance the grassy aromas. Medium-bodied with a some light dryness in the finish. Bitter and grassy flavours with the fruity and mild grain malts. So, much better than their American Pale Ale. Just not sure this one is an English-style one, as the hop is way present. Probably should be the American one instead.

500 mL bottle. Pours walnut with a nice white head and soapy lacing. Aromas of butter toffee, biscuit, fig, mixed nuts and bread. A hint of sweetness well balanced by bittering hop and a touch of earthy floral notes. Medium body and low to moderate carbonation. Well made and well enjoyed; would complement a meal.

Bottle [500ml]. Pours a hazy, bubbly golden-orange with an average size frothy off-white head. Aroma of bready caramel malt, floral hops, toffee, earthy notes and some fruit. Flavour follows the aroma, slightly sweet and bready, light floral hops and a moderate bitter finish. Average bodied. Textbook English-style, pretty good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Lots of malt with some tangy hops. Definitely an English style beer, and not a bad one and that. Creamy and very drinkable on the hottest day of the year.

Bottle from the LCBO. Moderately turbid body with a reddish-gold hue and a small white head. Aroma is pretty much textbook UK pale ale - biscuit, toffee, earthy tones, and subtle floral hops. Body is soft and lightly carbonated. Flavour starts with nice honey-toffee notes, followed some nutty earthiness in the middle, and a nicely bittered finish with a lingering, mineral-like dryness. Didnt impress me much at first, but by the end of the glass, I really enjoyed it!

500 ml bottle from the LCBO, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.: Hazy deep amber with a so-so white head.
 
Aroma: Very British with lots of earthy notes, dry toffee, faint raisins/dark dried fruits, fairly floral, alright.
 
Palate: Medium body, relaxed effervescence.
 
Flav.: Slightly sweeter, friendlier caramel/toffee, still fairly earthy and floral, appropriate, just not what I like; dry with fair bitterness and an earthy caramel/toffee and lightly floral finish.

Well-made. Not for me.

It pours amber with a slight brownish tint; the head is bone and foamy. The aroma has notes of: roasted grains, toast, burnt toffee, and wet grass. The taste is light bitter that finishes medium bitter; there are notes of: toast, pine, biscuit, and a grassy note. The palate is medium bodied, light-medium carbonation, and a long bitter finish. Overall, very light in profile - Renaissance has the quirk of making beers that smell way better than they taste.

500ml bottle from LCBO.  Looks nice - fairly clear orange-amber with a large-ish frothy beige head.  Smells like a light biscuity bitter with some floral/acidic bittering - ehh.  Taste follows, maybe a bit of orange peel, definitely a bit wort-y.  Light slick mouthfeel, weakly carbonated, quick malty floral finish, no aftertaste.  Ehhh.

Mostly malt in the aroma but a little hops. Pours cloudy orange with ok lacing and some head. Pretty explosive initial carbonation, but it ends up being pretty flat. Finishes sour with a bite of tinny astringency. Pretty boring import for the lcbo.

Malty, sweet, bready aroma. Hazy dark brown with a big, long lasting head. Looks nice. Pretty interesting beer, starts off with some herbal/resiny notes, ends with a faint sweetness on the tongue and a lingering bitterness. Very carbonated, medium bodied. Not overly refreshing or amazing, but still good.

500 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a murky copper colour with large, lasting off-white head that leaves some lace.  Aroma is toffee, biscuit, hints of fruit and some flowers.  Flavour is biscuity, toffeish malt, modest citric fruitiness with a nice floral hoppiness towards the end as well as some spicy and minerally character.  Lively carbonation.  Quite nice.

Bottle 500 ml 
Aroma: quiet malty with very solid depth. Great toffee nutty green hop play. Not just one sided approach here. Bolder secondary hop character Very refreshing 
Look: poured with large foam , thick creamy lasting with splendid lace. Bottom of slight haze on gold. 5- 
Taste and Palate: medium lighter bodied with fuller walls. Yeah this have in its core British genes but evolved with New Z twist. Tad spicy , tad fruity , bit tart. Its this modern interpretation? Well I love it. Great make over,

500ml bottle - decants an ale with a  clouded amber hue in the glass and a 2 finger puffy off white cap that lasts well and laces. Medium bodied, sandy mouth feel. Flavour profile has biscuit- toffee malts in front with a tart, berry like discernment ... mid palate we find some nut-like flavours and resinous hop balance that leads into a  decent bittering in the clean finish. Very well put together ale.

500ml bottle. Pours a hazy medium amber, with a smallish off-white head, which lasts reasonably well, and leaves decent lacing. Savoury crispbread, toffee and faint grassy hops make up the aroma. Grass and mild resin hops notes up front lead into a mix of biscuit, toffee and burnt caramel malt in the mid-palate, with more mild resin hops coming into the finish. This is a pretty decent beer without being too groundbreaking.
Kopparfärgad med vitt skum. Doftar karamellmalt, apelsin. lite sött, godis. Smakar söt malt, karamell, toffee. Avslutas med apelsinbitterhet, humle, gräs.
Well over carbonated but the base beer looks and tastes ok. Not the best of renaissance  though

Draught (fake cask?) at Dodson Street beer garden, Blenheim.
Pale amber, dry, moreish, clean, malt led with digestive biscuit and enough hops to balance.

28th August 2011Hazy amber beer, small white head. Crisp palate with a carbonated sting. Strong pale malt, with a mild raw taste. Orange hops bring the malt to heel and provide marmalade and a good bitter kick. Some fresh orange as well. Subtle dried fruits underneath, tangy. Crisp finish. Decent but needs more hop to be a top notch pale ale.

500ml bottle. Pours dark hazy golden colour, with lively off white colour head. Pleasant on the nose, nutty malt, floral hops, some doughy yeast. Good lively carbonation, maybe a little on the fizzy side. Coffee coming through in the tast, slightly roasted, fruity, very nice beer.

In bottle at Craigs. Pours a golden colour with a decent white head. Aroma of white pepper, lemon, saison yeast, caramel and alcohol. Similar flavours with moderate carbonation and CO2 prickle and a foamy mouth-feel. Lovely.
bottle at home ... golden amber ... big bubbly white head ...yeasty funky lemon saison nose ... little too fizzy ... light perry lemon ... soft fruits ..
I prefer this to the american pale ale they make. Still over carbonated though but a better beer all round

Bottle thanks to Harrisoni in Rome on our MesandSims stag do. Poured a clear dark gold amber. Pale ale aroma with some toffee and hops in the flavour. Pretty uneventful but certainly drinkable. It was up against some stiff competition that night though (thanks all, especially Alex). And to all who were there, how hot was that singer? Miaow.

500mL bottle. pours honey colour with a soapy head that lasted longer then i expected but not long. Aroma is a strong sweet citrus with a  hint of spice and it reminds me of murrays angry man pale ale. The citrus and spice definantly follows through to the flavour but its hard to pick up and malt as the citrus dominates.
Bottle. Slightly hazy golden with medium off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, hops and a little floral. Flavour is malt, little sweet, hops, fruit, little grapefruit and medium bitter.
Bottle from Ølbutikken. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are hops, raspberries, fruits, malt and citrus. Nice beer with pleasant bitterness.
Clear dark golden with a lasting white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and moderate hoppy - fruity. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 090212

Bottle in Rome during Mes stag do.  Clear copper gold colour.  OK pale ale has some character to it.  Some caramel.  Its again oxidised.  Not travelled well.  Some cabbage on the hop.  Does not work entirely
Pours a nice creamy head with soft toffee noted on the front palate,  Hoppy bitterness rolls over the top onto the back palate.  Full bodied.

500 ml bottle. Nice looking light-copper in the glass with decent head and remained cloudy and hazy. Light aroma of peaches that is gentle on the nose, but not overly fresh. Tastes of malt and fruit (more citrus than the peaches), but the hops shine through at the end leaving a bitter aftertaste. For me this is the weakest member of the Renaissance family, almost boring against its superb stable-mates, but still a highly drinkable ale.

0.5 l bottle from GBBF2011. Slightly hazy orange color. Orangey, grassy and slightly yeasty aroma. Toasty, biscuity, nutty and bitter flavor with orange and passionfruit. Yeasty bitterness in finish with some burnt toast.

One of the nicest bottled beers that I have tried in a long time.
Despite a number of trips to NZ I found it at the Great British Beer Festival 2011.

Im greeted by a thick, fluffy white head that appears to endure upon an orange amber hazy glass of enticing loveliness. However the initial nosing suggests a whiff of oyster sauce, earthy mustiness, old fruit and other things that Im not sure I like. Ive had this beer before and I know that this isnt typical.
Mercifully this beer tastes far better than it smells. Theres oranges, madeira cake, butter and bitterness that lingers. Pleasant enough, but getting over the disappointment  is going to be tough. This is a beer that is calling out for a re-rate later down the track. I faithfully promise to do just that.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Light hazy orange-golden with a big, frothy, off-white, bubbly head. Aroma has nice grassiness, fine grapefruit and some mild resiny notes. Crispy sweetish malt in the back. Highish carbonation, very dry and quite grainy mouthfeel. Flavour has mild grainy doughy malts at first, fine grassiness. Fairly harsh bitterness in the finish. Good, but not a perfect pale ale.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. This is much better than the APA. Pours a dark amber with a big, billowing white head. Aroma is pronounced piney hops and grapefruit. All the piney and grassy hops come through in the taste. Not completely balanced but I enjoy this one a lot. Great beer
Dufter dejligt af citrus frugter lidt cAramel, flot gylden farve med Hvidt skum smager super lækkert af cAramel og citrus... Ok fylde cAramel ialt en super lækker ale

Bottle. Pours clear orange with a creamy white head. The aroma is plastic like hops, fruit, citrus and caramel. Grassy hops, citrus and orange like hos in the flavour backed up by the caramel. Bitter finish with orange notes.

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar.
Clear amber coloured with a medium sized white head.
Fruity aroma of hops and grass with notes of pine needles.
Fruity flavour of hops and grass with notes of pine needles.
Hoppy finish.

Pours amber with a huge head.
Nose shows lots of grapefruit and pine alongside earthy and resinous hops. Also shows some sweet bready malt. Very English, but in a full-on hoppy way.
Similarly hoppy flavours with little in the way of malt backing, just a faint sweet bready note. Pleasant enough.
Moderate carbonation could really be higher.
Bottle at MikkellerBAR. Clear amber - white head. Toasted. Fruity. Medium hoppy. Grassy. Medium malty. Nice. Ok hoppy. Nice and fresh.

Draught at the Local Taphouse, Darlinghurst. Pours a cloudy gold, with a medium but thick off white head. Aroma is purely floral, and the flavours are floral, hint of ginger, spice (coriandor?), and a sweet caramel. Enjoyed this immensely

500ml bottle. This beer is all bubble and froth in the initial pour with a deep dense creamy head. Deep amber colour with some murkiness. Hop notes lead into some toffee like aromas and biscuity malt flavours finishes it off nicely with a bitter tang in the finsih. A good drop from a good brewery.
Mandarin gold and a huge head thats open and falls. Toffee malts and sharp resinous hops dominate in a very tasty pale ale way. A very good Pale Ale from enzed.

Bottle 500ml.Light unclear medium orange color with a average, frothy - fizzy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, fruity, moderate to light heavy hoppy, citrus - orange, fruity. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100709]
50 cL bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is roasted malty, light caramelish. Dry malty, slight ashtray hops. Herbal. Dry and bitter into a mild roasted finish.

cloudy orange or golden, small white head.
spicy yeasty aroma.
flavor is balanced, hoppy flowery and hoppy bitter, malty balance. fine.

Bottled. Light amber coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Aroma of flowers, caramel, bread. Flavour of flowers, spice, fruits and herbs. Light caramel. Medium bodied. Dry floral bitterness in the end.

Bottled. A hazy amber beer with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of citrusy hops, malt, and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel as well as subdued notes of hops lending it notes of citrus and elderflowers, leading to a bitter finish.

Bottle, 10C. Amber with a small tightly-packed beige head. Medium bead. Aroma: earth, fruit, resin and spice over toffee and shortcake. Taste has lots of butterscotch with earth and spices. Long, rather genteel bitterness. A tad heavy - I liked it but I didnt fancy another - and the malt character verged on caricature.

Bottle. Amber with scant head. Aroma is classic British butter. Has some sourness and hint of plum. Toasty bread malts. Quaffable palate with a relatively crisp finish in spite of the diacetyl, which is just within the realm of tolerability. Thin body. Then proceeds to a toasty finish. Flawed but not altogether bad.
Dull tan.  The aroma has light fruit, mincemeat tart and a little bit of butter.  On the palate, there is plenty of butter - toasted butter even - along with soft anglohops and light caramel.

500 ml bottle

Aroma: very hoppy and somewhat yeasty with a hint of apples or possibly berries, slight toffee and cookies (biscuits in NZ)  background not readily apparent  when it is cold
 
Appearance: brown clear with a minimal head and lacing

Taste: bitter with a hint of sweet and sourness

Palate: medium to full body, lightly creamy texture with a bitter finish that draws out into a nice mellow character

Overall: Nice, hoppy and a little complex

500 ml bottle.  Lovely light brown ale with thin head.  Malty nut and toffee flavours waft upwards with a hint of berry and resin.  Round and full on the tounge, quite bitter with a some not-unplesant sour notes.  Medium bodied and leaves a long resiny finish.  Fantastic pale ale; goes great with strong flavoured foods like blue cheese.
Light copper golden with white head.  Strong citrus hop.  Resinous hop flavour, with biscutty malt and bitter finish.

Big frothy head an amber pour little hazy,aroma malty caramel fruit honey toffee syrup nearly,flavour toffee a fruit bitter caramel fizz on the tongue has that taste of toffee apple a little tart but not bad as to spoil,goes down smoothly,citric peel bitter,finish smooth tasting,good bitter,with that added fizz on the palate.

500ml bottle batch 0053. Hazy amber hue, awesome huge foamy off white head, fully lasting, good lacing.  Crisp citrus and slightly floral hoppy aromas  with some caramel and dark honey aromas. Flavour is initially balanced with nice caramel toffee biscuit and citrus fruity hops,some green apple in there, then the hops dominate, the finish is long, and bitter, carbonation and mouth feel is soft.  A  nice beer, though of the Renaissance range  I would have reserved the "Perfection" name for the Elemental Porter over this one.

Bottle. Hazy orange amber, orange-tinted head. Aromatic hop aroma, lots of peaches, gooseberry, and orange rind. Sweet malts are almost lost in the hop load, fruity and perfumey, and the finish is surprisingly bitter-- seems like more than 45 IBUs to me. Very nice, but not very English to me (where are the fuggles, the earthiness, the tea-leaves?), but Im not complaining! Tasty.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Draught at Creek Pizzeria (opposite the Brewery), Blenheim. Pours dark golden with a small white head. Aroma of sweet malt, citrus fruits and hops. The flavour is malt, biscuit, citrus and fruit. Thin-medium bodied with low bitterness. A solid English PA.

500ml Bottle. Poured a hazy amber colour with a creamy off white head, awesome head retention. Aroma is very tart with hints of biscuit and caramel malt. Taste is creamy with a nice lingering tart bitterness with notes of carame,l toffee and biscuit. This is one of my favourite Renaissance beers, I could drink it in the winter or summer alike.

500mL bottle. Hoppy, spicy aroma. Malt and some honey. Vanilla notes. 
Flavours arent as sweet as the aromas let on. 
A strong, hoppy bitterness. Some spice and clove. Slightly peppery with some caramel.
A bitter finish that lingers. An amber/brown colour with a white head and nice lacing. 
Not the best of the Renaissance range but still very nice.

Luscious mangoes, pears and caramel aroma. Short lived small white head, slightly hazy dark gold colour. Honey, apple, blackberry and mango flavours. Nicely balanced with a firm bitter finish; the fruit notes really linger on the palate.

My 2nd attempt at this beer. The first one was flat, strangely enough the cap seemed secure too. 500mL bottle, cloudy light amber beer with a large white head. Hops dominate the aroma. Nice malt taste to this pale ale, and a pretty strong bitterness to end with. Very quenching and refreshing.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2009 15/5/08Draught from Regional wines. Pours amber with a fluffy white head. Caramel and hop aromas. Dry mouthfeel, bitter hops come through but dont hang around for long. A very nice, easy to drink pale ale. 
RERATE 7/3/09: 500mL bottle from Willis Metro New World. Pours hazy golden/amber.
Aroma is subtle in its flavours but by no means weak. Fruity esters dominate, some apple and spices with a caramel like malt there.
Flavour is well balanced between toffee malt and a sharp hop bitterness, with the latter lingering into the finish for quite some time. Those 45 IBUs do come through.
Enjoyable, the only thing detracting from my enjoyment is the sharpness of the hops.

This beer had a very strong creamy head, and the colour was moderately cloudy orange amber. There was a crisp hoppy aroma. There was malty citrus fruit, nutty yeasty flavours, and a bitter hoppy finish. This ale was very crisp with bitter flavours.

From the 4 pack purchased at Hillsdene Wine Cellars. This bottle poured a lovely copper colour with a light tan head which quickly disapated. The aroma is slightly biscuity and floral. Mouth feel is pleasant with a toffeish sweet malt flavour that finishes with a cleansing resiny bitterness. I had this one with some spicy curry and it was a terrific match.

(Bottle 50 cl) Slightly hazy, pale amber golden with a rough, white head. Citrus and caramel in the nose. Medium body, a little low in carbonation with a very soft mouthfeel. Plenty of caramel, lots of fruity flavours but otherwise completely dominated by distinct, citrusy hops that also leave a solid bitterness. Almost more like an APA. 040208

A monster!  Lots of pale malt and hops for a European-style Pale Ale.  A little hoppy for me, but its up front and doesnt linger.  The Renaissance brewpub in Blenheims a nice place to enjoy this brew, although I enjoyed mine in Akaroa on the Banks Peninsula near Christchurch.
Light and clear amber and slightly hazy body. Small head. Aroma dominated by hops and citrus. Fresh taste with fruit/citrus and hops and a bitter hopsy dry aftertaste.

Bottle, poured a clear amber with a large foamy off white head. Beautifully hopped aroma,flowery and malty. The palate is also strongly hopped, the malty flavour is earthy, with a long drying and resiny finish.

A good pale ale which could be great. Theres an "off" character to the aroma which I cant quite place, which is a shame, as its otherwise a nice mix of citrus, pine, and sweet malt. The flavour is similar to the aroma, though without any detectable off-notes. Just a hit of green apples which Im not sure should be there. Theres a very nice hint of mangos there too. Unusual, but very welcome. A slightly thin mouthfeel and a shorter-than-Id-like finish also lose a mark or two. Im sure there is a fantastic beer here trying to get out. Ill be retrying it regularly.
Nice cloudy pale orange colour with thin white head. Sweet grassy honey aroma. Mild grass hop flavour hint of citrus. Mild bitterness and good dry finish.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2008 Nose is a blend between ripe fruit (creamy mango nectar) and citrus hop, fruity body with a lovely bitter finish. Possibly needs a bit more malt balance but one of the most interesting New Zealand beers ive ever tried. Chill haze at low temperatures and low carbonation is true to type.

Nice mid gold colour but surprisingly cloudy for a fined beer. Big full dry hoppy nose. Fantastic flavours from the first taste. A touch under carbed for me. A bit more fizz & clearer & this is a hit.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2007 Thin low density head with good lacing. Slightly murky gold amber in colour. subdued nose of mild nose of mild hops with a fruity edge. You need to think about it (so to speak) but quite classical. Palate weight is light but again classically structured. Flint, bitter hops, grapefruit, resin from the hops. A fraction spicy on the finish. Light and easy drinking.Nov 2006 (3.2)On tap at the Malthouse in Wellington. Medium rusty orange with a very thin head. Fruity nose with a nice display of apricots. Elegant palate, more apricots, dry hoppy notes, some mineral and iron on the finish. Perhaps the intensity is just a touch mild but very well built.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2008 Retasted 07/06/2008.  I always liked the darker offerings and Renaissance are hitting their straps with the pale beers now too. Full malt character, big hop flavour, massive bitterness. Perhaps a shade too carbonated to let the flavours show through. It has all the positives of below without the fermentation issues. Good work.  Tasted 17/11/2006. Half at The Malthouse, Wellington. Pours an almost bright deep gold, thending amber, with a white head that thins out. Sweet caramel malts and tropical fruit notes, at first, but these get overwhelmed by a green apple aroma, reminiscent of sour apple chews, that dominates through the glass.  Big weighty mouthfeel carries little in the way of interesting malt characters and a very strong nettle-like bitterness.  Finishes very short, with a little more green apple on th palate.  The fourth time I’ve tried this and the green apples have definitely dominated the last three samples.  I like what they are trying to do with this pale ale but something’s not quite working.

(21 Dec 05) On tap at Black Creek.  Bright gold under a white head.  I wouldnt be surprised if this beer has been influenced by Roger Pink of the Pink Elephant Brewery as its aroma features Golden Tusks signature peach notes but has a caramalised character of its own.  The body is fruity with orange and citrus flavours and a distinct grapefruit-peel bitterness that grows into the long dry finish.
Draught at the brewpub.  Clear amber. Grassy mangoish hop aroma. Dryish and crisp with medium body. Really hoppy with strikingly bitterfinish.
